summary: This document contains official correspondence from the U.S. Virgin Islands Department of Justice to Jeffrey Epstein, notifying him of strict travel reporting requirements as a registered sex offender. It includes a notification form and a follow-up letter from Morocco confirming Epstein's travel there in April 2019. The document shows authorities monitoring Epstein's international movements.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Registered sex offender / recipient of travel notification
persons.context: The primary subject of the document; the Virgin Islands DOJ is notifying him of strict travel reporting requirements, and Moroccan authorities confirm his travel to Morocco in April 2019.

events.title: Epstein's travel to Morocco
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered and exited Morocco via Marrakech-Menara Airport, using passport #566672615.

events.title: Virgin Islands DOJ issues strict travel notification to Epstein
events.description: The U.S. Virgin Islands Department of Justice sent a letter to Jeffrey Epstein outlining stringent conditions for reporting any travel outside the territory, revoking previous provisions.

locations: St. Thomas, VI 00802-1348 (6100 Red Hook, Suite B3)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was subject to strict sex offender travel reporting requirements in the U.S. Virgin Islands, requiring in-person notification 21 days before international travel.
Moroccan authorities confirmed Epstein traveled to Morocco on April 25, 2019, entering and exiting via Marrakech-Menara Airport.
The Virgin Islands DOJ revoked previous, more lenient travel notification provisions for Epstein, requiring immediate compliance with stricter rules.
Failure to comply with the travel reporting requirements could result in prosecution under both Virgin Islands law (fines and imprisonment) and federal law (up to 10 years imprisonment).
The document shows coordination between U.S. consular officials in Casablanca and Moroccan national security authorities regarding Epstein's travel.
